stream_context.summary: Kaze worked almost exclusively on creating a single, complex platforming mechanic for the game's ice level: an ice platform that cracks and then shatters after being jumped on. The stream was a deep dive into the technical and artistic challenges of implementing this effect on N64 hardware, involving custom shaders, particle effects, and debugging. During this process, he also accidentally fixed a major, unrelated bug and announced he is expecting a child.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates that the overall project is approximately 80% complete.
development_findings.quote: The hex is just slightly over 80% done I would say.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is conscious of the N64's hardware limitations, avoiding certain animation techniques like scaling because they don't render well on the original console.
development_findings.quote: I think it needs a bit of a shake when it appears. I could try a scale in animation, but it would look kinda really poopy on N64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugs a complex visual effect, discovering the issue was caused by reading from a register that held an unexpected memory address (the display list head) instead of the intended timer value.
development_findings.quote: I was reading O-O-Timer. And O, in this scenario, is actually the S8 register. Which, while running on the graphics thread, is just the current display list head. So it was reading a random memory address instead of the timer.

development_findings.summary: A bug fix unintentionally removed an exploit-like move (a spinning triple jump). Kaze is undecided on whether to reimplement it, weighing if it's a desirable feature or an unintended cheese strategy.
development_findings.quote: I kind of accidentally fixed this thing. You know the thing where you can do this and then a triple jump? You can't do that anymore. Because a bug fix required changes to this.

development_findings.summary: The stream focused on creating a single platforming element for Course 13: an ice platform that cracks on the first jump and shatters on the second, requiring a complex custom shader and particle effects.
The game will feature a 'grind rail' mechanic, for which an animation is already planned.
development_findings.quote: Well there's grind rails and we still kind of have an animation plan for those.

development_findings.summary: Kaze provides a detailed technical explanation to a viewer on how to programmatically change Mario's colors when using a specific community-made patch (MatStackFix), demonstrating his deep knowledge of the decompilation project's intricacies.
development_findings.quote: If you have MatStackFix, then your Mario Party doesn't use light colors. Your Mario Party uses prim and nth color. So you need to generate prim and nth color for code instead of having it be hard coded in the model data.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, are expecting their first child in approximately two months. This is a major personal life event occurring during the game's development.
context_findings.quote: Wait, you guys didn't know I was going to have a kid? Yeah. We're going to have a kid in like two months.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong negative opinions about Mario 64 DS, criticizing its controls and the implementation of multiple playable characters, which he feels cripples the player by forcing them to switch.

Kaze believes it's often more time-efficient to delay bug fixing, as issues can sometimes resolve themselves accidentally during other development tasks, a philosophy he proves correct during the stream.
context_findings.quote: This is why I don't go bug fixing until like the very end, sometimes bugs just randomly get fixed like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a moment of existential reflection on his public identity, questioning whether he is perceived as a game developer or merely a content creator.
context_findings.quote: I am considered a YouTuber. This is it's over. Is this actually what my life has been this whole time? I've just been a YouTuber, not a game developer.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a cynical view on the integration of AI into society, suggesting its acceptance is tied to economic participation.
context_findings.quote: I think the only reason we need to keep AI out of most of the human spaces is because AI can't spend money on your website.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states he dislikes typical tourism, finding cities to be boring and similar, but is interested in visiting places with unique environments and purposes like conventions.
context_findings.quote: Visiting Comic Con sounds a lot more interesting than visiting New York or Paris. Because it's actually like a different environment, you know?

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed an idea for a platforming mechanic involving a path that appears as the player gets closer, which Kaze wants to implement despite not having planned for it in the current level layout.
biobak.quote: Biobak's appearing path thing, yes. I definitely want that in here. The thing is, I've modeled the whole castle so far without planning that in.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided Kaze with a .blend file containing a technical and artistic concept for the ice platform's dissolving effect, which Kaze then spent a significant portion of the stream trying to adapt and implement.
biobak.quote: Okay, I'll check the blend you sent me. I don't think I downloaded this last time. You mean icetest.blend?

biobak.summary: Biobak contributed to a thumbnail design for one of Kaze's upcoming YouTube videos, which featured a pastel rainbow color scheme.
biobak.quote: Updated post for the thumbnail. Let's see what we have here. All right, what do you think?

zeina.summary: Zeina is expecting a child with Kaze. Kaze jokes about their dynamic by suggesting Zeina wanted to name the child 'Reina', in the style of Mario's rivals (Wario, Waluigi).
zeina.quote: We're thinking of naming the child like Reina, as in like the rival of Zana. You know, like the evil Zana.

zeina.summary: When a viewer suggested Zeina could be his video editor, Kaze dismissed the idea, stating she isn't familiar with the technical specifics of his work, highlighting a separation between their personal life and the technical side of his development process.
zeina.quote: I don't think Zeina knows the technical details of what I'm doing at all.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze both subscribed to his Twitch channel during the stream.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Bug Fix
key_stories.summary: While developing a new feature, Kaze accidentally fixed a major, long-standing bug that another team member was struggling with. The incident served as a perfect illustration of his development philosophy that it's sometimes better to let bugs sit, as solutions can appear unexpectedly.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent and difficult bug was causing music and animations to fail when entering the second area of a level due to misaligned ROM pointers. Another contributor, Arthur, had been trying to fix it.
key_stories.process: While debugging a crash in the new code for the cracking ice platform, Kaze discovered he was reading from the wrong memory pointer. He realized the code he had copied as a template contained this same error. By fixing the pointer in his new code, he unintentionally resolved the original, widespread bug.
key_stories.outcome: The major bug was fixed entirely by accident. This validated Kaze's development philosophy of not always immediately tackling bugs, as sometimes the solution emerges organically from other work, saving time and effort.
key_stories.key_quote: I know Arthur wanted to fix this bug but I think I just fixed that whole thing on accident. All right, awesome. See, and this is why I don't go bug fixing until like the very end. Sometimes bugs just randomly get fixed like that.

key_stories.title: Crafting the Cracking Ice Platform
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent the majority of the stream on a single, complex platforming element. The process involved intense technical problem-solving, collaboration with Biobak, and a long iterative loop of tweaking visuals, culminating in a functional but imperfect result that highlights the difficulty of creating modern effects on old hardware.
key_stories.challenge: To create a visually convincing and mechanically sound ice platform for Course 13 that cracks on the first jump and shatters on the second, all within the technical constraints of the N64.
key_stories.process: Kaze began with a simple model and iterated through numerous ideas. He incorporated a shader concept from Biobak, which led to a deep dive into N64 material properties, using primitive colors, alpha channels, and dithering to simulate the effect. He then added and refined particle effects for the shattering, tweaking their color, velocity, and spawn patterns to hide visual imperfections.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a functional prototype with a multi-stage cracking and dissolving effect, complete with custom shaders and particle systems. Although functional, he remained unsatisfied with the final visual quality after the long and arduous process, deciding to leave it as-is for now.
key_stories.key_quote: I feel like I've looked at this for so long that anything that doesn't look completely jarring at this point looks fine to me. But like if I actually just play the game and I saw this effect, would I hate it? I don't know.

key_stories.title: The Impending Child
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed that he and his wife Zeina are expecting a child soon. This personal news provides a new lens through which to view the project's development, adding a layer of work-life balance and shifting priorities to his creative journey.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze and his wife Zeina are navigating a major life change—an impending child—while Kaze is in the late stages of a massive, multi-year creative project.
key_stories.process: Kaze casually announced to his stream that he and Zeina are expecting a child in two months. He engaged with the chat's reaction through humor, discussing potential names and joking about the baby's 'special abilities,' while also acknowledging the real-world impact it will have on his work schedule.
key_stories.outcome: The upcoming birth introduces a significant new variable into Kaze's life and work. It provides crucial personal context for the documentary, affecting his available time, priorities, and future plans for project showcases.
key_stories.key_quote: Actually, I don't know if I can do an F3 this year. Because I'm going to have a child releasing in a bit.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that a person named 'Eiza' has a 'special plan' for a release video for 'the slide,' and that Eiza wants to make it 'like a little bit of a documentary thing almost.'
questions: Who is Eiza and what is their relationship to the project?
What is 'the slide' that this video is for?
What are the specific plans for this 'documentary thing'? How does it relate to our documentary?
How does this planned video fit into the overall release strategy for the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he probably can't do an 'F3' this year because he's having a child.
questions: Is it a personal event, a community showcase like E3, or something else?
What role has F3 played in the development or release of your previous projects?
How does not doing an F3 this year impact the project's timeline or release?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak suggested an 'appearing path thing' inspired by Mario Galaxy, but that he hadn't planned for it in the current castle model. He mused about putting it in 'abyss rooms'.
questions: Can you describe the full concept for the 'appearing path' mechanic?
How do you two collaborate on design ideas like this?
What are the 'abyss rooms' and how might this mechanic be integrated there?
What is the process for deciding whether to add a new, unplanned feature late in development?

open_questions.context: Kaze accidentally fixed a major bug that another contributor, Arthur, had been working on.
questions: Who is Arthur and what is his role on the team?
What other contributions has he made to the project?
How does the team typically handle difficult bugs like the one that was fixed?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the game has 'grind rails' and that there is an animation plan for them.
questions: Can you describe the grind rail mechanic?
How far along is its implementation?
What is the animation plan you have for it?
